title: Monetizing passions, scaling marketplaces, and stories from a creator economy vet | Camille Hearst
key_insights: In marketplaces, supply is almost always the critical constraint - you can't have a business without inventory on the shelves
Consistency and predictability of content creation is crucial for creator success, along with collaboration with other creators
Musicians often struggle with the 'starving artist ethos' and shy away from monetization more than other creators
Start building relationships with potential acquirers from day one, not when you're ready to sell
Treat company acquisition like a managed process similar to fundraising - it rarely just happens organically
Focus on de-risking your biggest, most innovative ideas first rather than always choosing safe, predictable wins
Creators need two fundamental things: audience growth and monetization - audience growth often enables monetization opportunities
The creator economy prediction largely came true, but platforms won due to network effects and aggregation advantages

guest_background.current_role: Head of Fan Monetization at Spotify

topics_discussed: Working with musical artists and creators
Apple's product management approach vs traditional PM roles
Steve Jobs interaction and Apple culture
iTunes early days as second PM
memorable_quotes: I think they're two-sided and you start with the supply and at the end of the day, you can optimize for the demand side or choose who you're going to prioritize in terms of if there's a conflict, we're going to pick this side or the other.
The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago, the second best time is now.
We call it internally the hamster wheel of content creation. You get on because you love it and then how do you get off.
summary: Camille Hearst shares insights from her extensive creator economy experience, covering marketplace dynamics, creator monetization strategies, and practical lessons from building and selling a startup. The conversation provides valuable frameworks for product management and deep insights into the supply-side challenges of creator platforms.
